name: Visual Studio 2022
description: Visual Studio 2022 includes more support for Azure cloud tools, as well as support for .NET 6+. Now that .NET 5.0 is no longer in LTS, Visual Studio 2019 does not support any of the active versions of .NET

name: Native Azure Apps
description: Moving our APIs and Web Apps from cloud VMs into native apps on Azure could help us build and monitor them in a consistent way

name: Yaml build pipelines
description: Microsoft introduced the Yaml pipelines on Azure DevOps a few years ago and has been pushing it more, preferring it over the 'Classic' pipeline builder. Yaml builds do support the features of the Classic builder, while adding a lot of new features such as templates, and keep the template alongside the code it is meant to build

name: Shared build templates
description: Templates allow us to take a set of steps (such as building a .NET core solution) and repeating them in many places. If the steps need to be updated, we have only one place we need to apply the update to, and we reduce the variation between different pipelines to make it more reliable

name: Health checks
description: While moving to Azure Apps, Health checks allow us to quickly scan all of our API and Web apps to see that they are still running. We can also check that the response time of a health request is not much longer than expected (an early sign of a failing service), and use the health check as an easy and automated post-deployment test to find about any issues immediately

name: NCrunch
description: A powerful Visual Studio extension that runs tests in real time as the code changes, and provides in-line code coverage as well as highlighting areas of inefficiency

name: Three Amigos
description: A quick discussion between a developer, a tester, and a product owner or business analyst can help get everybody on the same page when starting a new piece of work, as well as highlighting any expected issues and edge cases early

name: Consolidating Azure DevOps projects
description: A number of potentially powerful Project Settings such as common Pull Request policies and common Variable groups are difficult to do without a lot of repetitive manual work to consistently apply them across our entire codebase. Bringing a lot of the older projects into the same project could make things a lot easier going forwards, while still keeping them in their own repositories

name: Low-code solutions
description: Allowing non-technical users to slice data could allow for quick and custom ways for our internal users to query large data sets, however we need to assess the data, the access privileges, and training requirements to consider this. PowerBI is one possible way this could be achieved, or perhaps the ChatGPT offering within Office365 ('Copilot') once it becomes available?

name: Classic build editor
description: The Classic editor is used for most of our build pipelines, however does not support consistent templates across builds, and Microsoft is moving away from it. New projects should aim to use Yaml pipelines instead

name: Alpha versions for NuGet packages
description: Publishing an alpha version of a package can allow the nuget package to be tested in another project, without marking it as 'Stable'. This can be automated to only build Stable packages from a key branch such as master, while feature branches can build Alpha packages to experiment with

name: Data-only Dev environments
description: Could we avoid having a DEV environment entirely if we only need the shared Database to support local development? What apps are difficult to maintain locally without lots of interconnected services all running?

name: Beyondtrust DefendPoint
description: Using admin accounts all the time could cause vulnerabilities, turning off network for admins can prevent some things from functioning, but we still need admin access on our laptops to achieve other things. Defendpoint could provide a middle-ground where a user who might need to run as an admin can do so, with only the smallest amount of elevated privileges they need to accomplish a single task, and audit logging by having to provide a justification for each use of admin access. https://www.beyondtrust.com/privilege-management/windows-mac

name: Combined build-and-release pipelines
description: Using Stages in a pipeline could allow us to have a strong workflow going from building, to releasing, to automated testing and promotion of artifacts with minimal fuss, and better monitoring. These can even be built into the pipeline templates to automatically set up the configuration for the different environments, offer different workflows for master or develop branches vs feature branches, and allow an easy way to update lots of releases all at once https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/devops/pipelines/get-started/key-pipelines-concepts?view=azure-devops

name: Terraform
description: Terraform offers an easy way to create and update environments, in a repeatable and reliable way. This can include configuring any security features such as subnets and IP restrictions, installing a minimal app with the right services available to it, and stay at a predictable price when running on the cloud

name: Automatic Linting
description: Code Linting tools can offer ways for us to improve the quality and consistency of our code, and make suggestions of changes we might otherwise not be aware of. Some of these can be code style suggestions, or avoiding known inefficiencies (E.g. Resharper, Stylecop), while other tools can point out security vulnerabilities (E.g. Whitesourcebolt, Sonarqube). Some of these changes can seem nitpicky or subjective, so it can be important to get the balance right with the suggestions, and not make them too intrusive
